title: react/jsx-quotes is deprecated. Use jsx-quotes instead
body: React/jsx-quotes has been deprecated in latest version of eslint.

title: Hyper Oslo using your style guide
body:
Hey guys,

The devs here at Hyper in Oslo, Norway love your style guide. Even though we didn't fork it (like normal people), we have a document based off of it here:

https://github.com/hyperoslo/javascript-playbook/blob/master/style.md

So thank you guys so much for putting this together, and if you feel like adding us to that list of yours then you're more than welcome!

title: Added max-len rule
body: Closes #509

title: No max-len ESLint rule?

labels.name: semver-minor: tighten rules to match guide

body: Is there a reason why there is no [max-len](http://eslint.org/docs/rules/max-len) rule present in your [rules](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/master/packages/eslint-config-airbnb/base/index.js)?

title: Added clarifying statement to React README
body: Added a clarifying statement to explain why the underscore prefix isn't used in React.

title: Allow unused function parameters.
body:
Hi,

I accordance with #426, here's a PR which allows unused function parameters. While I was doing it, I noticed #506, which this depends on (actually, it includes all those commits as well).

(Testing GitHub:) This Fixes #426 

Thanks!

title: Remove JSX from eslint-config-airbnb/base
body:
Hi,

JSX was present as an `ecmaFeature` in base, so I moved it to the react-specific settings. Also, because I would have had to add another loop for merging `ecmaFeatures`, I decided to just use lodash to merge base and react. All the tests (still) pass.

title: Added id-length rule to eslintrc
body:
This helps make sure variable names are longer than 1 character.

Single letter variable names are almost guaranteed to be completely non descriptive, this makes sure our variable names are longer than that.

Documentation on the id-length rule: http://eslint.org/docs/rules/id-length.html

title: Can iterators be pretty and immutable?
body:
I hope to start a discussion about [11.1](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/24dc126e4b11bb60d053fc6c93598488b9bf0455#11.1).

I bet you know _[trine](https://github.com/jussi-kalliokoski/trine)_. The whole concept of the lib is based on iterators – to have a unified set of functions working with any sort of collection. It looks very elegant and “native” to JS:

``` js
const characters = strings
    ::map(String.prototype.split::partial(""))
    ::reduce(Array.prototype.concat)
    .sort()
    ::uniq();
```

:+1: Using iterators this way doesn’t involve managing state, except when writing the utilies.

:+1: There’s no risk of mutating stuff. Every function is returns a new iterator.

:+1: One more bonus – the thing is lazy. So you can map over infinite collections, etc. Lots of functional programming goodness.

:-1: There’s one “but”. Working with iterators in such an elegant way is only possible with the [function bind syntax](https://github.com/zenparsing/es-function-bind). And that doesn’t come into the spec until ES 2016 (if at all). They do transpile cleanly to ES5 with babel though.

title: Blank lines between definitions in a class?
add semicolons to const declarations in 19.2
Filenames with different UpperCamelCase are unsafe in case-insensitive filesystems
body:
Using upper-camel-case for filenames, or any sort of case that involves different letter casing, is dangerous when your team includes developers committing code from case insensitive filesystems (mostly people with windows and NTFS, and OSX and case insensitive HFS+).

It's a problem specifically when a developer in a case insensitive filesystem renames a folder in a way that just changes the folder's case, and pushes it. Because github (and probably all git hosts) run on linux, you'll get an inconsistency there that you will not observe in an inconsistent file system.

For instance if you had `Button/Button.jsx` and `Button/style.css`, and you rename the button folder and file to `button/button.jsx`, in the remote git repository you would end up with two folders, `button/button.jsx` and `Button/style.css`. Nothing would be different in your local filesystem.

I understand if you strictly follow the conventions and never ever change a folder case you will be fine, but it's easy to overlook if someone does it.

title: Make eslintrc dependencies copy-pasteable
body: Saves me **minutes** every month

title: ES5 settings for eslint
body: There seem to be ES5 rules for `eslint` created by someone else: https://github.com/1hella/eslint-config-airbnb-es5 Wouldn't it be worth to merge these two projects and provide ES5 configuration out of the box the same way as the one for ES6 is?

title: Include the rationale behind the rules, if there is one.
body:
I realize that in some cases you may just have a stylistic preference ("We think this is more readable") and that in others, there is an objectively good reason for the rule that guards against programmers doing stupid things. But reading this guide does not illuminate that. For example, when I see "Wrap JSX tags in parentheses when they span more than one line" I'm not sure if that's just someone at AirBnB's style opinion or if there's a more objective reason.

So for everyone else in the world, it would be really nice to understand your reasons as we compare our own style rules to yours.

title: Default parameters go last.
body:
Do you think it's worthwhile to explicitly call out the order when only some parameters have a default? 

[The compiled output is pretty different](https://babeljs.io/repl/#?experimental=true&evaluate=true&loose=false&spec=false&code=%2F%2F%20bad%0Afunction%20handleThings%28opts%20%3D%20%7B%7D%2C%20name%29%20%7B%0A%20%20%2F%2F%20...%0A%7D%0A%0A%2F%2F%20good%0Afunction%20handleThings%28name%2C%20opts%20%3D%20%7B%7D%29%20%7B%0A%20%2F%2F%20...%0A%7D). Being new-ish to es6, this seems pretty important to note, but maybe too much of a NSD.

title: Sometimes there is a requirement to use _this
body: In the ES5 document it mentions using _this, but in ES6 it states () => {};. Surely there are occasions where _this is required? I use it sporadically of course, but I use it still.

title: do not export propTypes
body:
We decided to stick with the decision to not export `propTypes`, and leave them as only a static property on the default export.

/cc @goatslacker @gilbox

title: [react] inline export syntax
body: b more 1337

title: Underscore prefixes for "private" properties
body:
From the main section:

> Use a leading underscore `_` when naming private properties.

From the React section:

> Do not use underscore prefix for internal methods of a React component.

These two seem a bit inconsistent.

title: update spelling to clarify JSX rather than JS
body:
Hi, 

Noticed a small issue - the original React alignment section in the readme referred to the following code as "JS syntax" when it highlights use of "JSX syntax". Small difference, but just wanted to request the slight change to offer a little more clarity. 

Thanks and appreciate the style guide - super helpful!!

title: Request for more clarity on the specific reasons generators are discouraged
body:
"They don't transpile well".  Does that mean correctly?  Performance?  Code size?

I know this is Airbnb's guide, but given it appears to be the most popular ES6 style guide, more details could help other people make their own correct decisions.

title: Discourage use of const
body:
ES6 const does not provide read-only data structure.

> The const declaration creates a read-only named constant.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/const

The documentation is incorrect/misleading. It provides a constant reference to a value:

``` js
const foo = 'test';

foo = 'bar';
```

Produces:

```
Line 3: "foo" is read-only
```

Thats because `foo = 'bar'` is attempting to assign a new value reference.

However,

``` js
const foo = {};

foo.bar = 'bar';
```

Does not produce error, because value reference does not change – the value itself changes. Therefore, this is not a read-only value.

This creates false expectations about the data structure.
